column15: Description
Determine what APIs you intend to use and on a higher level how you want to leverage them.
Read all documentation provided for the project and get a firm understanding of what is expected of you.
Submit the tasks listed below to FSO.

Determine which visual framework you intent to use for the duration of the project.

Make certain to experiment and play around with multiple frameworks until you find one that suits your needs. 

Get a working knowledge with the code you may be working with so that you choose one that is flexible enough to fit your project.

Here is a list of Visual Frameworks to help you get started.

http://usablica.github.com/front-end-frameworks/compare.html?v=2.0
column25: Choose your Framework, submit to FSO

column15: Setup the base libraries and visual frameworks you intend to use. (Bootstrap, foundation 3, jeetframework, etc.)
Create the primary file structure.
Implement a simple version of your chosen API. This be a stand alone page in your project that pulls the API's desired information.
Create a simple one table database for the purpose of building upon it later. This is so that we can tie it into our project and know that the connection is working properly.
Add to the Database the basic tables and structure you anticipate for this project. You will likely refine these later so don't worry about getting them precisely perfect just yet.

This style guide will set the tone for all views. If / when later on in the project a new view is needed to be created you can reuse predesigned elements to achieve the desired look for the view without having to go through the wireframe process, speeding your development time.

Please use the resources linked below for further explanation. These assets you create should be placed into an ASSETS folder in your Github Repo.

http://styletil.es/
Create a Style Tile to define the look of this page.
Create a Style Tile to define the look of this page.
Create a Style Tile to define the look of this page.

Enhance your chosen visual framework to incorporate the elements defined in your Style Tiles.

Identify the unique elements from your Style Tiles and develop the markup to create those items as needed through your views.

Adapt your Visual Framework to be responsive. This will require the addition of media queries to create break points that reorganize elements on the page to more adequately utilize the available space.

Here is a great explanation of Responsive design versus the other options of Fixed and Adaptive. We will be targeting responsive as it allows us to define  approximate ranges of device sizes and be able to responsively deliver content to them.

 http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=alp9UI0SeIY

Review your code, designs, and other materials created to ensure they are commented, well formatted, and developed to a a standard that represents your personal best work. 

You will be handing off your project to other developers for review and you should be confident that your work will stand up to their scrutiny in addition to the rubric.

Full Description of the Peer Review Process

https://docs.google.com/document/d/1FvTSXVRmJD_TdatutzI4NfvlgItXy1nQUQCcEALLCY0/edit?usp=sharing
In a crowdsourced site or service the main focus of the site is generated by the users. Pictures, video, text, or other content, depending on the focus of your specific site need to CRUD as well.
Develop the base CRUD functionality for your project.

Password are easily crackable. Forcing users to create complex passwords is not intuitive for the user sign up process. This is a challenge that, as devs, we face today.

More reading on just how easy passwords are to crack - http://arstechnica.com/security/2013/03/how-i-became-a-password-cracker/

column2: Restricting Functionality and Access to Sensitive Areas and Features.
column15: Making certain a user is logged in to preform certain actions.

column2: Users should be able to positively signal a piece of content.
User should be able to easily report misuse of site.
Users can subscribe to other user's content feeds.

column15:
Review your code, designs, and other materials created to ensure they are commented, well formatted, and developed to a a standard that represents your personal best work.

column2: Users can create public profiles for themselves.
Users should be able to find contact information for support.

column15: How errors are displayed to users and logged for admin review.

column2: Dashboards should be populated with New, Popular, and Followed Content.
column15: Home pages are great for displaying popular or fresh content that a user has yet to discover.

column2: Users should be able to subscribe to newsletter.
Users should be able to find help in documentation.
column15: At minimum a FAQ section

column2: Users should be able to find and read terms and policies.
column15: Find a boilerplate Terms and Services agreement and modify it to your needs.

column2: Users should be able to find copyright information.

Create an well edited 2 min. video walk through of your app. Draw upon your skills in previous classes.

column2: Users can create and curate lists of content created by other users.
column15:
This allows users to essentially create groups or playlists of content.

Example: See Dribble Buckets - http://dribbble.com/_chapman/buckets

column2: User should be able to easily filter content based on meta tags
Content is required to be tagged with meta information upon submission.
column15: Comments are an essential part of any content sharing service.

column2: Users can share content to other social networks
column15:
Facebook has created some really easy to use tools to help you out. Here is a direct link to them. Enjoy! 

https://developers.facebook.com/docs/plugins/

column2: Advertisers should be able to show their products or services to make money.
column15: Google Ad words and other services offer viable revenue streams.

The ability to reach out to your audience is key. 

Create the ability for an admin user to send a templated email out to your subscribed users.

column2: Users should be able to see related content to what they are currently viewing.
column15: This further promotes content discovery.

column2: Users should be able to access recent activity in a data format such as JSON or RSS.
